attributes.name: uri
attributes.description:
When the URI attribute is set, `<apollo-client>` will asynchronously
create a new ApolloClient instance with some default parameters

attributes.name: validate-variables
attributes.description: When true, client will not fetch operations that do not have all their non-nullable variables set.

properties.description: Reference to the `ApolloClient` instance.

properties.name: elements
properties.description: List of all ApolloElements registered to this client.

properties.name: typePolicies
properties.description: Type Policies for the client.

tags.name: apollo-mutation
tags.description:
Simple Mutation component that takes a button or link-wrapped button as it's trigger.
When loading, it disables the button.
On error, it toasts a snackbar with the error message.
You can pass a `variables` object property,
or if all your variables properties are strings,
you can use the element's data attributes

attributes.name: input-key
attributes.description:
When set, variable data attributes will be packed into an
object property with the name of this property

attributes.name: refetch-queries
attributes.description:
A list of query names which will be refetched once this mutation has returned.
This is often used if you have a set of queries which may be affected by a mutation and will have to update.
Rather than writing a mutation query reducer (i.e. `updateQueries`) for this,
you can refetch the queries that will be affected
and achieve a consistent store once these queries return.
attributes.type: RefetchQueryDescription | ((result: FetchResult<Data<D>, Record<string, any>, Record<string, any>>) => RefetchQueryDescription) | null

attributes.name: loading
attributes.description: Whether a request is in flight.

properties.name: inputKey
properties.description:
When set, variable data attributes will be packed into an
object property with the name of this property

properties.name: mutation
properties.description: The mutation.

properties.name: refetchQueries
properties.description:
A list of query names which will be refetched once this mutation has returned.
This is often used if you have a set of queries which may be affected by a mutation and will have to update.
Rather than writing a mutation query reducer (i.e. `updateQueries`) for this,
you can refetch the queries that will be affected
and achieve a consistent store once these queries return.
properties.type: RefetchQueryDescription | ((result: FetchResult<Data<D>, Record<string, any>, Record<string, any>>) => RefetchQueryDescription) | null

properties.name: called
properties.description: Whether the mutation was called

properties.name: optimisticResponse
properties.description:
An object that represents the result of this mutation that
will be optimistically stored before the server has actually returned a
result.

This is most often used for optimistic UI, where we want to be able to see
the result of a mutation immediately, and update the UI later if any errors
appear.

properties.name: errorPolicy
properties.description: Specifies the ErrorPolicy to be used for this mutation.

properties.name: fetchPolicy
properties.description: Specifies the FetchPolicy to be used for this mutation.

properties.name: awaitRefetchQueries
properties.description:
Queries refetched as part of refetchQueries are handled asynchronously,
and are not waited on before the mutation is completed (resolved).
Setting this to true will make sure refetched queries are completed
before the mutation is considered done. false by default.

properties.name: ignoreResults
properties.description: If true, the returned data property will not update with the mutation result.

properties.name: document
properties.description:
GraphQL operation document i.e. query, subscription, or mutation.
Must be a parsed GraphQL DocumentNode, so use `graphql-tag`.
If unset, the element can derive the document from the first
light-DOM `<script type="application/graphql">` child.
properties.type: DocumentNode | TypedDocumentNode<{ [key: string]: any; }, { [key: string]: any; }> | null

properties.name: context
properties.description: Context passed to the link execution chain.

properties.name: variables
properties.description: An object that maps from the name of a variable as used in the mutation GraphQL document to that variable's value.

properties.name: client
properties.description: The Apollo Client instance.

properties.name: data
properties.description: Latest mutation data

properties.name: error
properties.description: Latest error

properties.name: errors
properties.description: Latest errors

properties.name: loading
properties.description: Whether a request is in flight.

events.name: will-mutate
events.description: When the element is about to mutate. Useful for setting variables. Prevent default to prevent mutation. Detail is `{ element: this }`

events.name: will-navigate
events.description: When the mutation resolves and the element is about to navigate. cancel the event to handle navigation yourself e.g. using a client-side router. . `detail` is `{ data: Data, element: this }`

events.name: mutation-completed
events.description: When the mutation resolves. `detail` is `{ data: Data, element: this }`

events.name: mutation-error
events.description: When the mutation is rejected. `detail` is `{ error: ApolloError, element: this }`

events.name: apollo-element-disconnected
events.description: when the element disconnects from the dom

events.name: apollo-element-connected
events.description: when the element connects to the dom

slots.name: trigger
slots.description: The triggering element. Must be a button or and anchor that wraps a button.

slots.name: variable
slots.description: An input with a `data-variable` attribute. It's `value` property gets the value for the corresponding variable.

cssParts.name: trigger
cssParts.description:
The container for the trigger.
See [`ApolloMutationInterface`](https://apolloelements.dev/api/interfaces/mutation) for more information on events
